June 27, 1982: Fiction
THE PARSIFAL MOSAIC, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $15.95.) Through
many exploits and hairbreadth escapes, Michael Havelock saves the world from
nuclear extinction.
THE MAN FROM ST. PETERSBURG, by Ken Follett. (Morrow, $14.50.) During a
mission to Britain on the eve of World War I, a Russian terrorist collides with his
own romantic past.
THE PRODIGAL DAUGHTER, by Jeffrey Archer. (Linden Press, $15.95.) A
sequel to the author's ''Kane & Abel,'' in which two children of those antagonists
marry one another.
THE ONE TREE, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.50.) Book
Two in the fantasy series, ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant.''
EDEN BURNING, by Belva Plain. (Delacorte, $15.95.) Romance and political
upheaval on a Caribbean island.
NORTH AND SOUTH, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95.) The
friendship of two wealthy families - one in Pennsylvania, the other in Carolina - is
strained by the Civil War.
FOR SPECIAL SERVICES, by John Gardner. (Coward, McCann & Geoghegan,
$9.95.) James Bond against his old enemy SPECTRE.
CELEBRITY, by Thomas Thompson. (Doubleday, $17.95.) A crime committed in
their boyhood comes back to haunt three young men.
DINNER AT THE HOMESICK RESTAURANT, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $13.50.)
Three children caught in the toils of their parents' past.
THY BROTHER'S WIFE, by Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner/Geis, $14.95.) Two
brothers, a priest and a senator, each in his own way, love the same woman.
TWICE SHY, by Dick Francis. (Putnam's, $13.95.) Greed at work in the world of
horse racing and computer programming.
FRIDAY, by Robert A. Heinlein. (Holt, Rinehart & Winston, $15.50.) The
adventures on Earth of an Artificial Person, a creature of genetic engineering, in
the service of a Boss in outer space.
PUBLIC SMILES, PRIVATE TEARS, by Helen Van Slyke with James Elward.
(Harper & Row, $13.50.) A woman has to choose between a career and marriage.
DUTCH SHEA, JR. by John Gregory Dunne. (Linden Press, $15.95.) The
unraveling of a low-life Los Angeles lawyer.
Non-Fiction
JANE FONDA'S WORKOUT BOOK, by Jane Fonda. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.)
An exercise book for women, seasoned with the film star's philosophy of physical
well-being.
LIVING, LOVING & LEARNING, by Leo Buscaglia. (Holt/Slack, $13.50.)
Inspirational talks by a University of Southern California professor.
NO BAD DOGS: The Woodhouse Way, by Barbara Woodhouse. (Summit,
$12.50.) Advice on training dogs by a British expert: tie-in to a television series.
RICHARD SIMMONS' NEVER-SAY-DIET COOKBOOK. (Warner, $15.95.) More
than 100 recipes by the Hollywood television personality and exercise guru.
THE FATE OF THE EARTH, by Jonathan Schell. (Knopf, $11.95.) Essays on the
dangers to life on earth from nuclear weapons.
A LIGHT IN THE ATTIC, by Shel Silverstein. (Harper & Row, $12.45.) Humor in
cartoons and verse.
AMERICA IN SEARCH OF ITSELF: The Making of the President, 1956-80, by
Theodore H. White. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) A summing-up by the historian of the
modern Presidency.
WHEN BAD THINGS HAPPEN TO GOOD PEOPLE, by Harold S. Kushner.
(Schocken, $10.95.) Comforting thoughts from a rabbi.
A FEW MINUTES WITH ANDY ROONEY, by Andrew A. Rooney. (Atheneum,
$12.95.) Reflections on contemporary life by the journalist and television
commentator.
WEIGHT WATCHERS 365-DAY MENU COOKBOOK. (New American Library,
$14.95.) A compilation of more than 500 new recipes.
THE UMPIRE STRIKES BACK, by Ron Luciano with David Fisher. (Bantam,
$12.95.) The opinions and memories of the oddball baseball umpire.
LATE INNINGS, by Roger Angell. (Simon & Schuster, $17.50.) Essays inspired by
the baseball seasons of 1977 to 1981.
HOLY BLOOD, HOLY GRAIL, by Michael Baigent, Richard Leigh and Henry
Lincoln. (Delacorte, $15.95.) Some extraordinary conclusions about the lineage of
Christ, based upon old documents uncovered by three BBC producers.
